BC-SCIENCE-TIMES-BUDGET-NYT 
   The New York Times News Service plans the following    Science
Times    stories for papers of Tuesday, Aug. 1:

   SCI-EYE-SURGERY (Undated) _ Although the Food and Drug
Administration approved the procedure only two years ago, Lasik,
short for laser in-situ keratomileusis, has quickly grown into a $3
billion-a-year industry, with 750,000 Americans expected to choose
the surgery this year. Intended to correct nearsightedness, the
procedure can now treat farsightedness as well. With 1.2 million
American customers expected next year, Lasik is becoming the issue
in a financial turf war between ophthalmologists and optometrists,
between top-dollar surgeons and low-cost, high-volume centers. By
Kenneth Chang. (1900 words)

   With graphic.

   With

   SCI-EYE-WITNESS (Undated) _ A personal experience with laser eye
surgery which resulted in better than 20/20 vision. By Sarah Lyall.
(1080 words)

   And

   SCI-EYE-DECIDE (Undated) _ Considerations to be made before
going through with this laser eye surgery. (325 words)

   SCI-CALIF-ANTS (La Jolla, Calif.) _ Because of a quirk of
evolution and genetics, Argentine ants are taking over California
while forming what scientists believe could be the biggest ant
colony in the world, stretching over 600 miles from San Diego to
San Francisco. The ants in this so-called supercolony are nearly
identical genetically so that different colonies do not fight one
another the way they do in their homeland. As a result they are
using a united family front to win territory from native ants. By
Jon Christensen. (1785 words)

   SCI-PHYSICS-PARTICLES (Undated) _ Scientists announced that they
have succeeded in producing millions of well-known, if somewhat
obscure, particles called B mesons along with their antimatter
counterparts and plan to compare the decay rates of B's and
anti-B's with a precision that has never before been possible. The
comparison should provide a new measuring stick of one of nature's
most basic symmetries _ or asymmetries. By James Glanz. (1700
words)

   SCI-DYSON-PHYSICS (Undated) _ An interview with Dr. Freeman J.
Dyson, the British-born theoretical physicist, astrophysicist and
author of books on scientific matters. He discusses WWII, the NASA
Mars program and his opposition to the newest version of the
Strategic Defense Initiative. By Claudia Dreifus. (1715 words)

   SCI-GABON-FOREST (Undated) _ Ending a conflict over the fate of
a forest rich in both wood and wildlife, loggers, biologists and
the government of Gabon have agreed to keep bulldozers and chain
saws out of a 1,900 square mile reserve with the highest density of
large mammals ever recorded in a tropical rain forest. By Andrew C.
Revkin. (1100 words)

   SCI-VINES-BUTTERFLIES (Undated) _ Heliconius butterflies have
acquired aggressive survival techniques like feeding on cyanide
carrying passion vines which make them posionous to pedators, and
has caused the plant to develop defensive tactics of its own.
Biologists suspect that this interaction between the vine and the
butterfly over millions of years caused their evolution into
different species. By Nicholas Wade. (1550 words)

   With photos, NYT4,5.

   SCI-SETI-TELESCOPE (Undated) _ The world's most powerful radio
telescope designed to listen for signals that may be coming from
civilizations elsewhere in the galaxy will be built at the Hat
Creek Observatory, 290 miles northeast of San Francisco. By John
Noble Wilford. (380 words)

   SCI-WATCH () _ News and notes on science: Items on the possible
discovery of a new moon orbiting Jupiter, transferred eye tissue
generating an eye on sightless fish. By Henry Fountain.

   SCI-TONSILS (Undated) _ The FDA has approved an new medical
technique that will shrink tonsils as an alternative to
tonsillectomies. The technique involves inserting tiny needle
electrodes into the tonsils to deliver radio frequency energy and
claims to be less painful and also allows a quicker recovery. But
experts caution that the technique is still highly experimental and
not likely to be widely adopted until more testing is done. By
Andrew Pollack. (770 words).

   SCI-CANCER-DRUG (Undated) _ Though just beginning Phase 3 trials
and still somewhat uncertain, cancer specialists are seeing
exceptionally promising results in cancer treatments in trials
involving head and neck cancers _ and a possible drug that attacks
cancer cells but leaves other ones alone. It is based on a
defective virus that can grow only in cancer cells. By Nicholas
Wade.

   SCI-AMERICN-YOGA (Undated) _ The popularity of New American
Yoga, and its varied Western approaches. And American yoga is
becoming pervasive. By Ann Powers (1700 words)

   SCI-BRODY-HEALTH (Undated) _ The Personal Health column: Experts
agree that fibromyalgia, (an ailment characterized by chronic
widespread musculoskeletal pain) is a real illness, and advise
medication to improve sleep, exercise and psychological counseling.
By Jane E. Brody. (1240 words)

   SCI-VITAL-SIGNS (Undated) _ News and notes on health and
fitness:

   _ Most antibiotic misuse stem from patients wanting medicine and
doctors in a hurry to get to their next patient researchers at
Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston report. (240 words)

   _ The British Medical Journal reports that babies born during at
night (after 9 p.m.) were twice as likely to die within their first
week and this may be caused by the medical staff's increased
fatigue during the night and/or overreliance on a less experienced
staff. (175 words)

   _ The journal Neurology reported last week that the brain of a
ecstasy drug abuser had 50 percent to 80 percent lower levels of
serotonin and the other chemicals associated with it. This is the
first study to show that ecstasy can deplete the level of serotonin
in humans. Further research may show whether supplementing
serotonin levels could help addicts seeking to go through
withdrawal. (225 words)

   _ These days the Broadway musical's modern choreography is far
more rigorous and physical for its dancers and even some actors.

   _ A new study in the American Journal of Psychiatry found the
average young man wants to look like Superman, and believes women
want men to look like Superman, however women really prefer men to
look like Clark Kent. The study focused on what researchers have
come to call muscle dysmorphia (a syndrome in which men become
obsessed with fears that they are small and frail, in many ways the
flip side of anorexia nervosa.) The danger of men with these
anxieties is the risk of steroid abuse and over-exercising. (320
words)

   With photo.

   _ The Archives of Family Medicine suggests that many patients
may be escaping diagnosis because of what is called ``white coat
normotension'' _ high blood pressure that does not appear in
medical office readings. Researchers suggested that physicians
should feel confident only about office readings that were clearly
at one end of the scale or another. (260 words)

   SCI-Q&A (Undated) _ A science question answered: Why are
slightly more than half of all twins born are male. By C. Claiborne
Ray. (290 words)

   Photos, where indicated, are being sent to NYT photo clients.
Graphics, to NYT graphic clients. Non-subscribers can make
individual purchase by calling (888) 603-1036 or (212) 556-4204.

   Some ScienceTimes stories are available to international clients
only by special arrangement, and are so marked. Asian and European
points: contact Karl Horwitz in Paris for details and prices
(Phone: 47 42 17 11; FAX: 47-42-80-44).
